feed.title: gusev.io

Peter Gusev's (a.k.a. peetonn) site.
Immersive interactive experiences.
Real-time distributed systems.

entry.title: Entropy Bound
entry.content:
Entropy Bound is an interactive theatrical performance for humans, artificial intelligence and media.

‚ÄúThe holographic bound defines how much information can be contained in a specified region of space‚Ä¶ The universal entropy bound defines how much information can be carried by a mass ùìÇ of diameter ùëë.‚Äù
‚Äì Jacob D. Bekenstein, 1972

A woman, not capable of forming long-term memories due to a brain injury, becomes an early adopter of an AI brain implant device. The story evolves around her trying to find a way to relate to and utilize the new technology inside her head, by training it and learning from it at the same time.

Accompanied by her close ones, who have their own peculiarities, she tries to form new memories with the help of the implant, but inevitably starts to follow triggered associations and falls in a local minima of the old memories she does not remember.

Technological experiments were aimed to imagine how such a device might look like. A system prototype powering hypothetical brain implant was built during the workshop.

The main input for the system is a live video feed, captured by a POV camera, worn by the actress.

Video is streamed to a number of real-time ML (Machine Learning) processors for recognizing objects, theatrical props and faces. Each processor produces semantic frame annotations, by specifying recognized entities, their position on the frame and recognition confidence levels.

Based on these frame annotations, a feature vector, describing frame contents is built for the future frame comparisons.

Video stream and frame annotations are stored in the repo ‚Äì the brain implant‚Äôs memory. The repo is designed in a way that any data stored there can be accessed at any time by any other module.

A ‚ÄúScene Segmenter‚Äù module detects scene changes in the video stream in real-time, by utilizing semantic information from generated annotations. Scene segments stored in the repo, too.

Finally, a separate module, uses calculated feature vectors to query repo for the scenes, that are most closely resemble currently observed frame. Therefore, brain implant may ask its‚Äô memory something, like ‚Äúgive me 5 scenes from the past that look similar to what I‚Äôm seeing right now‚Äù.

Additionally, a brain implant user is able to add emotional context (using emoji) to video frames when forming memories.

When all components are live and operating, the live feed is being semantically annotated frame-by-frame, while being captured for storage and analyzed for scenes based on the semantic context. Scenes from the past (how far back we can go and comparison function are configurable), are continuously retrieved from the storage for presentation onstage and act as evoked memories (associations). In story words, brain implant triggers memories from the past that relate in some way to what is being currently observed.

Each system component is a separate module: C++ or Python app, some of them (ML processors) are containerized using Docker. For communication and video streaming, we used NDN over Layer2, thus all machines were connected to the same LAN segment.

Video feed from wearable lipstick camera is fed over SDI to the Capture TouchDesigner machine, where it is compressed and published over NDN using NDN-RTC Out TOP built using NDN-RTC library specifically for this workshop. Edge node and Repo machines are connected over NDN to the same LAN. Edge node runs three Dockerized ML processors ‚Äì OpenFace, YOLO1 and YOLO2 for faces, objects and props recognition respectively. Scene Segmenter as well as Memory Trigger are running on the same machine.

Edge node and Repo fetch NDN-RTC stream from the Capture machine. Repo stores video frames and makes them available immediately for historical fetching. Frame annotations published over NDN by ann publisher module. Annotations are fetched by the Repo, Scene Segmenter, Memory Trigger, as well as by other modules.

Video stream is also consumed by Master and Viz machines. The former allows for real-time monitoring and control of the whole system: Edge node and Repo statuses, detected scenes and triggered memories. Viz machine performs compositing of the visuals (TRACE) that are being projected in space.

An additional Monitor machine is fetching ML annotations and detected scenes information.

This data is then being sent over to the ‚Äúdebug‚Äù Info laptop, connected over WiFi. Info machine is connected to ceiling projector, this way it is always easy to monitor how the system performs by looking up at the projection. Master node also sends start and end frames for detected scene segments to the Info machine for display.

Projection system includes a 10K projector and two 4K projectors. Composited and rendered visuals are streamed over NDI from the Viz node to the projection machine.

10K was projecting on the back wall, while two 4Ks covered left-stage and right-stage decorations (cubes).

The workshop allowed us to experiment and explore limits of the technologies used. Using NDN as main communication network turned out to be successful. Connection-less, data-centric nature of NDN allowed us to avoid many problems with low-latency data dissemination across multiple agents. Since every data packet has unique name, implementing Repo was rather straightforward (RocksDB as a backend storage).
Some additional work needs to be done for ML part of the system, specifically scene detection and comparison.

TouchDesigner UI for the Master Node ‚Üí

Ceiling projection of the Info node ‚Üí
entry.summary: Entropy Bound is an interactive theatrical performance for humans, artificial intelligence and media.

entry.title: cheLA residence
entry.content:
In the beginning of March 2018 REMAP, where I currently work, and a number of invited interactive media and visual artists moved down to cheLA, Buenos Aires, for two weeks to organize a workshop for local artists and conduct a series of experiments using OpenPTrack motion tracking system, computer vision and machine-learning techniques for a live performance. The theme of the workshop was ‚Äúinteractive spaces with memory‚Äù.

A lot was built during these two weeks, which deserves a separate post I‚Äôll write some time later, but I‚Äôm glad I had a chance to work back to back with artists, engineers and professionals. It was a valuable experience and I gained knowledge that helped me to understand better my relationship with the emerging world defined by intersection of technology, art and performance. Due to unforeseen reasons, I couldn‚Äôt return back to Los Angeles after the project was over and had to stay few more months in Buenos Aires. Looking back now, I can say that this unexpectedly turned out to be a very productive time for me to submerge deeper into art, meet local and international artists, as well as learn new skills and apply them in practice. cheLA staff were kind enough to allow me to continue my stay in the space and use it‚Äôs facilities for my experimentations.

cheLA (/Centro Hipermedi√°tico Experimental Latinoamericano/) is a cultural and technological center, located in Parque Patricios, Buenos Aires, Argentina. It started its‚Äô existence in 2003 when Fabian Wagmister , UCLA professor and founding director or REMAP, acquired old asbestos factory with the goal of turning it into a place, where artists could work and experiment with modern technology. Today, cheLA offers its‚Äô spaces for artistic residencies, various art&technology workshops and makers studios. It is a huge building, with multiple interconnected warehouse-like spaces, community areas and apartments for residency artists.

After my team departed, I was left to myself at cheLA for a few weeks before next art residency started. It made sense to use this time to start learning and experimenting with what I always wanted, but couldn‚Äôt find time nor place to do it ‚Äî projection mapping. There are different techniques for projection mapping. The most simple one is based on 2D masking, where you point projector on the object you want to map and mask out areas that should remain black. You do this by drawing 2D shapes around the surfaces of the object, which should receive projected visual content (most likely videos or real-time generated visuals).

The first experiment, together with Matthew and Zoe, was to project on an weirdly-looking structure ‚Äî a giant paraboloid on the 2nd floor in cheLA (the structure was an experiment built during one of the architectural workshops held by TaMaCo).

2D mapping is fast and fun technique to use, when you need to quickly projection map something, for example, this airstair at cheLA apartments, where I stayed.

In my experiments I used TouchDesigner ‚Äî a node-based programming environment for creative coders, media and visual artists. My previous experience with it was mostly project-scoped and focused on engineering, rather than creative, side of it. Now it was a good time to explore other facets of this powerful system. TouchDesigner has a small, but very supportive community, where people share their knowledge through tutorials and forum discussions. I‚Äôd recommend anyone, who wants to learn TouchDesigner, use available tutorials on the official website as a starting point. It is a very interactive system ‚Äî every change is reflected instantly and visually, so it‚Äôs quite easy to grasp basic principles. The more difficult part is to find your own way of expressing your artwork through the system. This is something that is learned through practice. What‚Äôs interesting about studying TouchDesigner ‚Äî is that any knowledge, learned or discovered, is valuable as it may be applied in unexpected scenarios. This happened to me while I was following one particular tutorial on dynamic environment mapping for LED panels using GLSL. While I didn‚Äôt have LED panels at my disposal at cheLA, at some point halfway through the tutorial it struck me, that I can adapt the system for making anamorphic projection in a corner between two walls. The idea behind anamorphic projections is that the projected content makes sense (spatially) only when viewed from a certain point. This and this would be good examples of what anamorphic projections are.

The goal of anamorphic projection is to make graphical content be recognizable only when viewed from a specific position in space. Viewed from another angle, the content will be distorted, often times considerably, and won‚Äôt make any sense for a viewer. Unlike 2D projection mapping, this type of projection requires additional knowledge about the actual physical space: * geometry of the /projection surface/; * /projector‚Äôs/ physical location relative to the projection surface; * /viewpoint‚Äôs/ physical location relative to the projection surface. In my case, the projection surface was a corner between two walls. There could be two ways of finding projectors‚Äô location relative to the surface. The first one, is to actually measure physical distances between projector and walls and use them to model the scene in 3D. This will take a lot of time and totally depends on the accuracy of the measurements. The second, is to use TouchDesigner‚Äôs 3D projection mapping tool. All I needed to do is to mark /ABCDEF/ points on the actual walls and make sure projection area covered all of the points. Then, you perform mapping between physical /ABCDEF/ surface and a virtual 3D version of it (modeled as two perpendicular rectangles). The process is straightforward and interactive: you select a vertex of your 3D model and then move it‚Äôs projected marker onto its‚Äô corresponding point on the physical surface. By the end of this process, a transformation matrix is calculated, representing position of the projector relative to the projection surface, and is applied to the projector‚Äôs output. This allows to transform projection media in a way, that it will ‚Äúlay down‚Äù on the physical surface without distortions. Typically, you would assign textures to your projection surface 3D model and you will see them perfectly aligned with the physical structure. But with anamorphic projection additional work is required. The content must be rendered for a specific, predefined point of view (I chose it arbitrarily - approximately 6ft away from each wall and the floor). This essentially means that your viewer is represented as a camera inside TouchDesigner. The goal is, then, a) to move the viewer-camera in 3D scene according to the viewpoint in physical space and b) render content for this camera using mapping surface as a rendering canvas. The mapping surface essentially serves as a ‚Äúwindow‚Äù into the virtual 3D environment of your content. I wouldn‚Äôt know where to start with implementing this in TouchDesigner, but it turned out that it can be eloquently implemented using GLSL. For those who are interested, there is a sample GLSL code that can be adapted for this task.

The idea of interpreting viewer as a camera and mapping surface as a window turned out to be very useful for my next experiment. Just by moving camera you can specify new viewpoint for projection in the physical space. Or, if you turn it the other way around ‚Äî when your viewer moves in space, you just have to update the location of the camera in 3D scene to maintain illusion of a ‚Äúwindow‚Äù into the virtual world. Track a person in real-time? I think we have a solution for that‚Ä¶üò¨ Next several days I was experimenting inside the space, where we set up OpenPTrack system for the workshop in March. After some additional 3D modeling and pulling OpenPTrack data into the system, I was very satisfied with the result. I still need to learn a lot in TouchDesigner to make it look prettier or visually more exciting, but as a prototype and learning exercise, I think it worked out fine =) And I was quite happy I happened to be at cheLA at this time, where I could easily run experiments, trying and combining multiple different techniques and components, from 3D mapping and GLSL, to person tracking and anamorphic projections.

These days, cheLA offers its‚Äô spaces for regular art residencies, workshops, open studios, various art events, etc., more often than it used to be. We were pleased to contribute to this growth, by building something for cheLA. There is a space called Caldera, with an antique giant boiler, which on its‚Äô own looks quite impressive, serving as a reminder of the huge asbestos factory this building once was. And in this space, there are colored LED lanterns installed, hanging from the ceiling. These lanterns were programmed some time ago for an interactive installation and were never used again since then. Lanterns are controlled by a power supply box (Phillips Color Kinetics) which reads commands from the network it is connected to. There are a total of 6 lanterns; each lantern has 33 rows of colored LED strips. To set the color, one needs to send a bitmap array 33x6: each column represents one lantern, each pixel in a row represents lantern‚Äôs LED row.

Few days of testing and Touch-coding allowed me to build a graphical interface for controlling lanterns. After the networking part was done in Python (mostly by borrowing code from the installation repo), it was up to my imagination how color pattern for the lanterns might be generated. I implemented four pattern-generation modules: constant, gradient, animated drop and audio equalizer. You can find a demonstration here of how it ended up looking. Interface was implemented in such a way, so that anyone can add modules in plug-and-play fashion ‚Äî they just need to follow pre-defined rules.

Looking back now, unexpectedly extended stay at cheLA offered me an opportunity, at the right time and the right place. I seen all cycles of cheLA: full of people running projects, visitors attending workshops, art events and parties, art residencies and open studios, emptiness and silence. And it guided me through my own cycles of working, learning, thinking, absorbing community, reflecting back, re-thinking‚Ä¶ I‚Äôll be glad to come back to cheLA one day again, as an artist, collaborator or just a visitor.
entry.summary: In the beginning of March 2018 REMAP, where I currently work, and a number of invited interactive media and visual artists moved down to cheLA, Buenos Aires, for two weeks to organize a workshop for local artists and conduct a series of experiments using OpenPTrack motion tracking system, computer vision and machine-learning techniques for a live performance. The theme of the workshop was ‚Äúinteractive spaces with memory‚Äù.
